Maybe someone's already pointed this out, but the nodes/anti-nodes have nothing to do with the device itself and everything to do with the way the sound waves are bouncing around the room.  This is true of any sound in any room except for an anechoic chamber.  In an anechoic chamber this wouldn't occur due to there being almost no reflected sound.  The volume of each frequency would remain constant.

The nodes you are hearing as you move your head around the room is because the sound is a sine wave, and it happens without the fire machine and at all frequencies (not just the ones that are in tune with the fire machine. If the sinewave that bounces off two walls has equal to, but opposite (phase), level to the sound direct from the speaker it will give a node. All sound do it but a mix of sines waves (which most sound is) has nodes at different places so you never get full cancelation and it is not noticeable.

I also have a hypothesis that sound waves are spirals with 12 steps total. 11 before it repeats itself from the starting point one spiral (or frequency) lower or higher and not a wave running consistent down a line. because if it were consistent with a line than it would always return back to that root (or beginning) pitch. which is true, but running the notes consecutive with eachother moving forward or backward either brings you to a higher or lower octave of the original starting point, which adds dynamic deeper than a straight line.

I have a simplistic design of a 2.5ft x 2.5ft box with about 3,000+ holes in a square pattern similar to the Pyro Board from Fyshics channel. im lucky to have a CNC machine available to help make accurate holes and precise chamfers but limited to a 40" x 20" travel. Also, since I have this as my project I cant really make it exactly the same :(. so I need to put my physics and Ingenuity skills to the test and create a whole new type of plane from the rubens tube. :D I just need to get a deeper understanding of how the vibrations travel through the gas and how, that if its possible, make it so that I create a plane but it... ahh cant speak anymore might give it away ;)

I'm sure that this has been pointed out before.  In your diagram you have the points where the flames are highest labelled as anti-nodes.  These are the locations where the gas in the tube has a constant pressure and therefore they give the location of the nodes.  The anti-nodes are where the flames are smallest.

First of all: nice and most appreciated set of experiments and videos.

There is a flaw in the explanation of the multi bunsen regarding nodes and anti-nodes.

The energy in the gas is conserved. At a motion nodes the energy takes form of higher pressure (i.e a pressure anti node). At motion anti nodes the pressure is minimum (those are pressure nodes). Gas escapes at pressure anti nodes, i.e at motion nodes. The description shows reverse.

It is interesting how the nodes at different frequencies have the size that they do on the Ruben's array.
Speed of sound = 340.29 meters per second in air which is .
(1,116 feet per second).

 It gives some sense of the speed at which sound propagates through air.

The wavelength of a sound is it's velocity (ie, the speed of sound) divided by the frequency of the sound;
wavelength = speed of sound  / frequency;

 This experiment suggests that an array of Ruben's tubes would be far more interesting if it was larger, so more nodes could fit onto the surface to form larger patterns.. bass notes (ie, sub woofer 100hz and lower audio range wavelength is around 10 feet.)
 For rock music something at least that size would be necessary.

 A much larger and higher resolution grid might look really amazing.. although it would be best seen from above looking down onto the patterns generated.

 One can imaging applications such as controllable flames for industry and sonic components in engine ignition/burning systems.. or enhancing/ enabling chemical reactions and oxidizations that would otherwise be impossible to produce.. could have applications for renewable energy too if it could work like a kind of sonic catalyst.

Engineers usually try to remove noise from machines as sound and noise signifies lost energy..  energy that is usually lost as noise could be thought of in a different way.. as something that could be possibly be utilized to help drive reactions perhaps..

This isn't related to the video at all but I don't know a lot of people who are experts at relativity and im not particularly good at maths so i can't just learn relativity myself so I thought i might ask you. I understand that motion alters the rate of time duration and also affects distances. The way i was explained this was if for example one person was traveling in one direction faster than another person. Then a beam of light was fired in the same direction as the person moving faster. Since the speed of light is constant for all inertial frames of reference, the person moving with the light must adjust time to travel slower and distances to become shorter so the light can cover more distance in less time and result in the same perceived speed. But what if for example, a beam of light was fired from the other direction, the person is now traveling against the light, which means that the light would look faster. But since light travels at the same speed, time must go by faster and distances must become longer so that the light can cover less distance in more time, giving the same speed for light. But how is this possible? How can the person moving faster than the other person have both slower time and faster time, both shorter distances and longer distances. What happens when a beam of light is fired both from ahead and behind?

Hey Veratasium, I have a few technical concerns about the physics here. It is important to make a distinction between pressure nodes and displacement nodes. As you know, a node is where the variation in the relevant quantity is zero (zero pressure variation or zero gas particle vibrational motion, respectively), but the location of pressure nodes and displacement nodes are out of phase (in 1D, pressure nodes occur at displacement antinodes, and vice versa). At 1:40, we see the fundamental standing wave in the box, and observe stronger flames at the sides of the box where the gas molecules cannot move perpendicular to the container walls. At these points, the pressure variation is maximized, so we conclude that maximum flames occur at PRESSURE antinodes. By this reasoning, the animation shown at 0:33 is incorrect because is shows maximum gas particle motion where the flames are largest.

this is a good idea but I think it needs improvements : the fire is heating air and creating convection, but on a tube, the flames are where air goes up, here air goes up in the middle of the board but on the corners, the air is flowing towards the center. That is why the fire isn't going up but bends toward the center of the board. If it wasn't a board but a few pipes next to each other, air could go between the pipes and the fire would be straighter. Of course the pipes would have to be high enough for air to go under them.
